main_text:
To the extent that Continental and analytic approaches to feminism
differ, they do so primarily in the theoretical resources to which
they appeal: analytic approaches typically take their starting point
from philosophers in the English-speaking world – Russell,
Moore, Quine et al. – while Continental approaches typically
take theirs either from Germany – Hegel, Marx, the Frankfurt
School et al. – or from France – Lacan, Kristeva, Derrida
et al. Yet feminist philosophers are not always wedded to one
tradition over the other; both analytic and Continental feminists look
to the French philosopher, Simone de Beauvoir, for example, and both
find theoretical resources in the works of J.L. Austin and Michel
Foucault. Feminist work also often reveals the theoretical advantages
of crossing the lines between analytic and Continental philosophy and
between the two branches of Continental feminism. Indeed, Ann Garry
recommends “that feminists use methodological distinctions very
sparingly, that is, only when they are needed to avoid confusion or
are otherwise extremely helpful” (2018, 23). Thus, although this entry
distinguishes broadly analytic and broadly Continental feminist
traditions, it also tries to clarify intersections and overlaps
between the two traditions as well as the ways in which feminists
within them build on one another’s work. The entry focuses on
three topics common to the two traditions: problems of who or what
women are, issues pertaining to freedom and domination, and questions
of epistemic injustice.
entry_title: Intersections Between Analytic and Continental Feminism
hierarchy_title: Intersections Between Analytic and Continental Feminism || Preamble
